title: Thursday, 21st April, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Morning, welcome to Markets Live

PM

Drowning

PM

And there's plenty of other stuff going on

11:01 am
PM

From VW to the ECB

PM

But i thought we might start with this chap...

PM

11:02 am
PM

Lord Hanson

PM

Good few years since he died, but part of his business empire is headed back to the London market

PM

But they've dropped his name!

11:03 am
PM

Hanson Building Products become.... Forterra

PM

What kind of name is that for a British brick maker?

PM

Must have been some legal reason for changing the name, surely

11:04 am
PM

It's this float

PM

http://www.investe...1604210700078532V/

PM

Led by Credit Suisse

11:04 am
PM

Lone Star exit

PM

danger

PM

Is British brick making a growth industry? Dunno

11:05 am
PM

Sure we need to build lots of houses...

PM

But Loe Star is selling down...

PM

70m shares on offer at 180p apiece

11:06 am
PM

Every have any dealings with Hanson Bryce?

BE

Nope, before my time. I'd note, though, that Hanson's name lives on in the form of Hanson White.

BE

The maker of humorous greetings cards. https://www.ukgree...r-products/hanson/

11:06 am
PM

Ah Lord White, yes

PM

Big into the horses

BE

Which was, I think, the first business he and Gordon White founded. Found a niche importing cards from the US.

11:06 am
BE

On which they built an aggregates empire.

PM

Our Angela Mackay (now Asia director) did White over -- on his horses, etc

PM

WHen she was at the Times

11:07 am
PM

Anyway, we should concentrate on today

BE

Sure. Though since you mention it, here's Hanson White's current logo.

BE

11:08 am
BE

Which I have a tendency to misread.

BE

But enough of that.

undefined
11:08 am
PM

So the Footsie is off

PM

And it's very mixed

PM

And we get the ECB a little after noon

11:08 am
BE

Lots of ex divs, it being a Thursday.

PM

(TheLeggie -- it was the ICI bid that undid, and triggered Angela's attack...)

BE

BAE, Capita .... Plus Glencore and Tesco, if either still paid divis.

11:09 am
BE

Sky leading us down though.

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 978.00, down 50 (-4.86%), High: 1,030, Low: 976.50, Volume: 3.73m
PM

http://www.investe...1604210700078529V/

11:10 am
BE

Headline results fine, detail not.

BE

Customer churn up.

BE

In the UK, where it's apparently cut down on that process where you phone up to cancel and they put you on a cheaper deal.

11:11 am
BE

And in Germany, where customers are rolling off long-term contracts and are cancelling at the first opportunity.

PM

And in Italy, no?

BE

Yup. Italy, where there's a bit of a price war.

11:12 am
BE

Sky's much like any company that sells people things they don't really want.

BE

You need to keep replacing the customers at a rate at which they cancel. Same as spread betting firms, services insurers, etc.

PM

And subscription news media

11:13 am
PM

censored

BE

Well, indeed. But censored .

BE

So while the numbers are, on the face of it, ahead of consensus, the pace at which Sky is having to work to restock just keep accelerating.

11:15 am
BE

(@roddy1234: I think the impact of Sportsdevil etc is more of a concern for Sky than Netflix and Amazon, but I seem to be alone in that view.)

BE

Cazenove can summarise the detail per territory.

BE

 UK & Ireland: The UK business saw an increase in churn to 10.7% (vs
10.2% JPMe) with the company limiting discounts (Sky estimates that an
extra c10k customers churned due to the discounting policy). TV net adds
came in at +35k (vs. our estimates of +30k) and retail customer additions
were +70k (vs +65k JPMe). Broadband growth of +46k was a touch below
our +50k JPMe with the quarter having been more focused on Sky Q
marketing. ARPU of £47 was in-line with our estimate. Revenues of
£6,161m were +0.2% vs our estimate of £6,151m and EBIT of £1,154m was
+1.7% ahead of JPMe (of £1,135m) and +1.8% ahead of ZoneFinance
consensus.

11:15 am
BE

 Germany & Austria: Churn remained at 9.8%, a touch better than our
10.0% estimate, and as a result TV net adds came in slightly better than we
expected (+73k vs +65k JPMe). ARPU was in-line at €35. Revenues of
£1,079m for 9M 16 were broadly in-line with JPM/consensus of
£1,077m/£1,076m, and 9M 16 EBIT was also broadly in-line at -£33m
(JPMe/consensus -£32m/-£30m). We note that this is the first Q3 qtr in
which Germany & Austria has been profitable, and excluding the impact
of the change in amortization profile of Bundesliga rights, the operating
loss for the 9M was -£16m and a £7m improvement YoY.

BE

 Italy: Net adds of +34k were much stronger than expected (JPMe +15k)
despite the loss of Champions League, which did result in higher churn at
11.0% though (a touch higher than our 10.8% estimate). Revenues of
£1,475m were broadly in-line (JPMe/consensus £1,470m/£1,471m) while
EBIT was also broadly in-line with our estimate though slightly below
consensus (£22m vs JPMe/consensus £21m/£26m). We note that there was
one-off investment of £16m in relation to connected boxes and box sets
marketing.

PM

I didn't know about Sportsdevil . Is this free?

11:16 am
BE

Yes, and probably illegal.

BE

But if you have a Google around what's available on Kodi ....

BE

.... I've .... um .... been told that there's no particular need to actually buy anything, content wise.

11:18 am
BE

There's the Napster argument here, of course.

BE

Services that nick stuff tend to die quite quickly.

BE

But as they die, new services tend to replace them and nick stuff more efficiently.

11:19 am
PM

This is true

BE

Honestly -- a FireTV stick with Kodi sideloaded will give you access to basically every channel in the world and every film produced in the past 20 years, ad free and in decent quality.

BE

Um ....... I've been told.

11:20 am
BE

Back to Sky, though. Back to Sky, with its entirely sustainable business model.

PM

hahahaha

BE

Morgan Stanley's house broker.

11:21 am
BE

Numbers were in line, with a UK EBITA beat offsetting a small miss in
Italy. Net adds were slack in the UK, given the focus on the Q launch,
but KPIs in Italy and Germany were encouraging as new products begin
to have an effect. Consensus FY 16 EBITA forecasts of £1574m are likely
to stay largely unchanged. The stock faces a down year in EPS in FY17
as the new EPL costs kick in and uncertainty over the Bundesliga and
mobile. At 16-17x EPS FY16-17 and a c6.2% FCF yield valuation does not
stand out, but the shares may edge better after recent
underperformance.
Financials in line: Group 9m revenue is up 5% constant currency at £8715m
vs our £8719m. The EBITA outturn of £1143m was marginally higher than our
£1139m and up 12% constant currency.
For Q3, this implies that revenue was up 5% actual at £2297m (MSe £3001m,
2015 Q3 £2841m) with EBITA up 13% actual at £396m ( MSe £392m).
UK beat: On financials, the beat was all in the UK where Sky made 9m revenue
of £6161m (MSe £6147m) growth of 5.7%. UK EBITA was £1154m, £18m
ahead of our forecast of £1136m. EBITA growth at 9m was 15%. The drop
through of incremental revenue to profit in the UK was 43%, in line with H1
(revenue up £347m, EBITA up £150m).
Italy small miss: Italy saw a 2% decline (H1 3%) in constant currency revenue
at £1475m (MSe £1484m) (Q1 was -4%) with H1 EBITA at £22m, imply a loss
of £3m in Q3 (MSe £33m, H1 was £25m). The revenue decline reflected lower
subscriber numbers. Sky makes the point that there has been incremental
investment in connected boxes and box set marketing of c£16m yoy in the 9m.

BE

Germany marginal Q3 profit: Germany had revenue marginally short of
expectations at £1079m (MSe £1088m) up 10% at constant currency as in H1.
The 9m EBITA loss was £33m (MSe £30m loss). Sky highlights that the £2m
profit in Q3 is the first ever such Q3 profit in SkyD’s history.
Sky bought SkyD and Sky Italia for £7.2bn in 2014. The businesses jointly
contributed a loss of £11m in the first nine months of FY16. Sky observes that
it only gained full control of SkyD six months ago and both Italy and Germany
are being repositioned with new , more attractive , higher ARPU products with
wider distribution and the introduction of Sky Online.
KPIs slow in the UK, good elsewhere:
UK slow: UK net customer adds at 70k was in line with consensus but below
our 90k. The quarter saw heavy marketing of the new Q product which
detracted from the marketing effort put behind other products. The quarter
saw 11K standalone broadband adds implying just 35k TV adds. This follows
though a very strong H1 (retail customers up 205k, strongest Q2 in 10 years)
and probably just demonstrates that pay TV needs marketing to sell it. Sky
declares itself happy with the response to SkyQ launched in February but there
is no information on subscriber numbers thus far. Churn ticked up to 10.7% in
the quarter (MSe 10.5%) with Sky cutting back on ‘offer riders’. This impacted
churn by c10k customers. Churn ex this was c10.4%. ARPU was unchanged yoy
and QonQ at £47.
Italy better: Net adds were unexpectedly high at 34k ( MSe 10k), the
strongest quarterly add growth in four years, on the back of marketing of the
new Sky Box sets service, on demand and with the TI IPTV marketing . Churn
was slightly higher than expected at 11% reflecting weeding out of ‘offer
riders’ (MSe 10%) and ARPU was in line at €42.
Germany adds still not taking off ; Net adds were in line with expectations
at 73k ( MSe 75k), meaning c350k adds in 12 months in this underpenetrated
market, still a bit lacklustre. Churn was broadly flat at 9.8% (MSe 10%) and
ARPU was sustained at €35. The focus in the quarter was on selling the new
higher priced Entertainment Pack with 40% of adds in the quarter choosing
this option (at €21.99 vs €16.99) driving new customer ARPU growth of €2
yoy. Sky is moving to edge up prices and move customers off 24 month
contracts.

BE

Skipping a bit.

11:22 am
BE

Consensus forecasts: Overall not much changed - UK EBITA may rise, offset
by trimming in Germany and Italy: We think consensus forecasts will be largely
unchanged . We are on £1574m of EBITA in FY16, up 12.5% with eps of 61.9p
(+11%). Consensus UK numbers may edge up a bit after another beat,
Germany ( we have €15m) should remain unchanged but some upper end
forecasts (some have €35m-€40m for the year) may fall. Italian numbers may
also edge back slightly (we have €79m, css is €60-70m)
Key forthcoming issues: The key influences are (i) the impending Bundesliga
auction ( starts end May , finishes by June 10) where we suspect Sky and the
market will be relieved to see a rights renewal - even at a highly inflated price.
The Bundesliga has targeted getting inflation of 30-77% for its rights. We have
60% inflation in our numbers for SkyD, €780m pa (from €486m pa). (ii)
Further details on the Sky Mobile launch. Sky will launch UK mobile via its
MVNO with O2 in H2 2016. Sky is ambitious - CEO Jeremy Darroch: ‘ It is
going to be a major new category for us... a big leg of growth... …a serious
business.’ This is likely to put more pressure on short term forecasts although
the market likes this style of big growth driving project from Sky. We have
£50m of losses for FY17. The decision on the O2- Three merger (Sky would
greatly benefit from the merger being allowed with enhanced MVNO rights
from O2-Three) is due on or before May 19. (iii) The new EPL rights cost comes
through in FY17 ( June year end) with a £632m increase in the payment,
meaning we get a down year of earnings in FY17 (57.6p versus 61.9p in FY16).
Valuation: We expect 2016/17 to be a down year of EPS (MS 59p) as Sky
absorbs the £632m pa inflation in the EPL costs. Sky does not stand out at
17.2x calendarised 2016e EPS, dropping to 16.3x calendarised in 2017 (FCF
yield 6.2% and 6.4%). The shares have underperformed and getting a
lacklustre Q3 out of the way may mean some bounce in the shares.

PM

Not much bouncing today

BE

And as @Helen rightly points out, Sky will never trade at an undisturbed price because it's an option on whatever Murdoch's thinking at any given moment.

11:23 am
BE

Which is, to put it politely, a quite unpredictable variable.

undefined
PM

Some miners

11:24 am
PM

Given request on the right

BE

Sure. Not a lot new to say though.

PM

Anglo, SOuth32..

11:24 am
BE

Anglo's production report's mixed, because production reports are always mixed.

BE

That's the nature of production reports. But Anglo's also up 161% in the year to date, so .....

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 772.90, down 19.1 (-2.41%), High: 814.60, Low: 771.40, Volume: 6.28m
11:25 am
PM

161%!

BE

Yeah, you'd have thought shareholders would want to reward management for this blistering performance.

BE

And yet .............

11:26 am
BE

In terms of news, FY guidance is unchanged.

BE

Diamond supply chain -- the only bit people care about, really -- seems to be destocking gradually.

BE

Let me hoof up some comment here, just to summarise so we can keep moving. Here's BMO.

11:28 am
BE

Anglo American reported Q1/16 production results that were a slight miss vs. our expectations overall; however, the company has reiterated its previous production guidance for all of its major commodities. Diamonds, copper and nickel were largely in line with our estimates (+2%, -3%, and +3% vs. our estimates, respectively), whereas iron ore, metallurgical coal, export thermal coal and refined platinum were below our estimates (-12%, -14% -7%, and -56% vs. our estimates respectively). As a reminder, Anglo American does not report quarterly financial results (financials are reportedtwo times per year).

BE


Focussing on the differences: Refined platinum production was impacted by a Section 54 safety stoppage at the Precious Metal Refinery (PMR), which shut the PMR for 12 days and impacted production over the next 37, as well as a planned shut-down for a stock take. Nonetheless, platinum produced in concentrate of 567koz was only 4% below ourforecast. Iron ore production of 8.9Mt (-18% on Q4/15) from Kumba was the main driver for the miss to our forecast,with Sishen continuing to experience feedstock constraints as well as a Section 54 stoppage at Kolomela. Meanwhile, Minas Rio production reached 3.3Mt, which was broadly in line with forecast and showing a slight (+3%) improvement over Q4/15. Metallurgical coal production was impacted by longwall moves at Moranbah and Grasstree.

Positively, Nickel production at Barro Alto has now reached nameplate capacity following the successful furnace rebuilds.

Looking ahead, whilst production was a slight miss overall versus our estimates, the company has reiterated itsprevious production guidance, therefore, at this stage, we would expect the shortfalls to be made up over the balance of the year.

BE

As for South 32 .........

11:28 am
PM

http://www.investe...1604210700088588V/

PM

Shares up 5%

PM

94p

11:29 am
PM

It's a clean quarterly update i think

BE

Yeah, have to say, it looks decent.

PM

Graham Kerr insisting he's focused on value not volume

11:30 am
BE

Admirably simple and moves it into net cash.

BE

Production bang in line.

BE

There's a question about whether it's missed the window to buy assets at properly distressed prices, but I'm not sure I believe that even after I typed it.

11:31 am
BE

Still a lot of stuff for sale, officially speaking, and S32's name gets linked to basically all of it.

BE

Here's Barclays.

BE

South32 delivered a decent production quarter in 3Q with all key assets tracking in line or ahead of our FY estimates. The company reiterated production guidance for all operations, as well as controllable cost reductions and capex. The only material operational change was the ramp up of manganese ore production in South Africa in response to very strong market conditions (YTD production 81% of our estimate). Importantly, the company reported a US$134m decline in net debt since Dec-15, reaching a net cash position of US$18m as of end March. This was despite a $30m FX related increase in finance leases and $23m of one-off redundancy costs. The implied underlying FCF generation is therefore $748m annualized, or ~11% FCF yield. We remain Equal Weight on the stock.

11:32 am
BE

Alumina (19% of 2016 EBITDA): Output in 3Q16 of 1.33mt increased 2% QoQ and YTD production is tracking at 76% of our FY estimate. This was driven by a bounce back in output at Worsley (+5% QoQ) following calciner maintenance in the prior quarter. Additional maintenance is scheduled in the Dec-16 quarter. Guidance was unchanged at 3.95mt for FY16. Brazilian alumina production was down 4% QoQ and guidance of 1.32mt remains unchanged.

· Aluminium (15% of 2016 EBITDA): Production in 3Q16 at 240kt was flat QoQ and YTD production is tracking at 76% of our FY estimate. South African production declined 1% QoQ as pot relining activity was deferred for the remainder of FY16. Despite that FY production is expected to be flat YoY due to lower power outages. Mozal aluminium operations were stable.

· Illawarra met coal (7% of 2016 EBITDA): Total coal sales at Illawarra rose 44% QoQ reflecting the start up of the Appin Area 9 longwall. YTD sales volumes are tracking at 69% of our FY estimate. The Appin Area 9 project was completed in the quarter and commissioned following a slight delay from initially guided 2HFY16. The project will help Illawarra sustain production at current levels, and capex came in 33% below the original budget of US$845 million. Production guidance was unchanged at 8.25mt for FY16.

· SA energy coal (25% of 2016 EBITDA): Production in 3Q16 of 7.7mt declined marginally, by 5% QoQ and -17% YoY. YTD production is tracking at 75% of our FY estimate and guidance was unchanged at 31.95mt for FY16.

· Manganese (10% of 2016 EBITDA): Ore production in Australia was up 2% QoQ (9% YoY), with seasonal impacts in Australia immaterial. Ore sales volumes were a record in a quarter with wild swings in price. YTD ore production is tracking at 76% of our FY estimate and guidance is unchanged. Alloys production in Australia took a hit down 37% QoQ as electrictity shortages in Tasmania forced the closure of 2 out of 4 furnaces and reduced load on the remaining capacity. These are expected to return to action by June. Operations in South Africa improved with ore production bouncing 161% QoQ as mining activity was restarted in response to better prices, with capacity targeted at 2.9mtpa (100% basis). YTD ore production is tracking at 81% of our FY estimate. Manganese alloy production remained low, down 12% QoQ (-68% YoY) following the previous decision to shut down 3 of the 4 furnaces in South Africa due to low profitability.

· Base metals (23% of 2016 EBITDA): Nickel production at Cerro Matoso rose 10% QoQ as grades and throughput rose following maintenance in Q2. YTD production is tracking at 76% of our FY estimate. Meanwhile silver production at Cannington declined 20% QoQ as throughput declined 18% due to a mill outage, with further maintenance to come in May and August. Silver production YTD is tracking at 75% of our FY estimate. Production guidance for nickel, silver and zinc was unchanged at 36.5kt, 21.65moz and 80kt respectively.

BE

BHP's spinoff of South32 does look odd, in retrospect, given its balance sheet was built for armageddon.

BE

Which BHP isn't.

11:01 am
PM

Drowning in trading statements today

PM

Something a bit different...

PM

Every hear of DJI Holdings?

11:34 am
BE

Nope.

PM

Little 10m placing this morning, on the back of this news...

PM

DJI Holdings plc (AIM: DJI, "the Group", "DJI"), a provider of technology for the promotion and transaction of online bookings, mobile payments and lottery sales in China, announces that it will invest and cooperate with Beijing NewNet Science & Technology Development Co., Ltd. ("NewNet"), which has secured a partnership with Xinhuatong Network Co., Ltd. ("Xinhuatong") and branch offices of Xinhua News Agency ("Xinhua"), the national news agency in China, to supply game technology platform and facilitate mobile payments through the Xinhua News Mobile App for public utility bills including electricity, gas, water, mobile phone top-ups and traffic fines in an initial seven of 12 targeted provinces in China.

DJI's investment in this new venture will be funded by the proceeds of a placing of new ordinary shares in the Company to raise approximately £10.5 million before expenses through Mirabaud Securities LLP, at a price of 60p per share (the "Placing Price")(the "Placing").

11:34 am
PM

Xinhua is the official news agency of the Chinese government. Xinhua launched its mobile news app in June 2015 and is reported to have already registered 120 million by February 2016. It is expected that the recent average growth of 10 million users per month will continue into the foreseeable future as the app develops additional functionality and the partners believe that the app will reach 300 million registered users during 2017. Xinhua's stated intent is for the Xinhua News Mobile App to become a leading mobile unified information platform for all Chinese citizens.

The partnership between Xinhua, Xinhuatong and NewNet is intended to facilitate mobile payments via the Xinhua News App across China. Xinhua News operates through provincial agencies, each responsible for gathering and disseminating news locally. To date, seven provinces, with a combined utility spend of more than RMB 1 trillion in 2014, have agreed to launch this mobile payment facility through the Xinhua News App and a further five are targeted for launch in the coming months.

PM

http://www.investe...1604210802598852V/

PM

Lots more detail there

11:35 am
PM

Now, i'm usually a tad cynical about Chinese plays listed in London

PM

But this seems an extraordinary deal

BE

(@RNS: Apologies, I'll have to delete that comment as it's not our job to wear others' legal risk.)

11:35 am
PM

The immediate opportunity for DJI's platform to facilitate payments through the Xinhua News App is substantial and will utilise its existing relationships with key channel service providers, as well as working direct to customer, through this rapidly growing app. Each of the initial areas in which this facility will be deployed is a very significant market. In 2014, approximately RMB 4.3 trillion (£475 billion) was spent on electricity, water, gas, waste disposal, toll fees and broadband. Mobile phone top-ups totalled approximately RMB614 billion (£67 billion) in the same year and traffic fines approximately RMB 211 billion (£23 billion).

PM

They are having to beef up the board and give it some chinese characteristics

PM

The Board of Directors currently comprises Darren Mercer as CEO together with Lord Mancroft as Non-executive Chairman and Robert Lerwill as Senior Independent Non-executive Director. The Board recognises the need to strengthen its membership as it grows and intends in the coming weeks to appoint a CFO and representatives of its Chinese operations.

11:36 am
DJI Holdings PLC (DJI:LSE): Last: 65.70, down 3.3 (-4.78%), Volume: 739.55k
PM

Placing was at 60p

PM

Im not saying anyone should rush into it

11:37 am
PM

Just saying it warrants proper investigation

PM

Oh, it's also joining Nasdaq

PM

Need to keep an eye on that

11:37 am
undefined
BE

So, someone mentioned Smiths.

Smiths Group PLC (SMIN:LSE): Last: 1,153, up 45.3 (+4.09%), High: 1,171, Low: 1,140, Volume: 849.61k
11:38 am
BE

Buying Morpho Detection from Safran.

BE

Basically doubling down on Detection. Going for scale to fix one of its less good businesses.

BE

Makes sense and a decent price, says the sellside.

11:40 am
BE

With not much to say about wider question about what it means for Smiths' strategy.

BE

As in, will it finally actually break up? Or is this a signal that they'll buy to build?

BE

Or perhaps both, or neither. Dunno. Credit Suisse incoming.

11:41 am
BE

Morpho's CT technology
complements Smiths X-ray technology providing a broad technology offering. The
acquisition also opens up the US checked in air baggage market, where
previously Smiths Detection had no exposure despite the market being among
the largest globally. Morpho generates more than 50% of revenue from the aftermarket vs.
Detection at 38% and has an 18% operating margin vs. the current 12% for
Smiths Detection.

BE

Synergies. Management claim annual cost synergies of £21m will be delivered
by year 3 of ownership. Management forecast integration costs of c£21m
predominantly in years 1 and 2. There is also scope for revenue synergies but
these have not been disclosed. The deal will also provide a tax step up benefit for
Smiths (est. NPV £76m).

BE

■ Acquisition multiples. Acquisition EV of £493m equates to 2.2x historic sales
and 10.1x historic EBITDA, or 7.1x incl. synergies. Smith's currently trades on
10.1x EV/EBITDA and Safran bought Morpho for 2.7x historic sales in 2009. We
estimate Smiths 2017 net debt/EBITDA post deal will be 2.3x (pre-synergies).
Deal is expected to close in early 2017.
■ Financial Impact. Management state 'mid-single digit EPS accretion in first full
year of ownership'. This scenario would equate to CS 2017 EPS of 83p on a
proforma basis. Also post tax ROIC is expected to exceed c8% WACC in year 3
of ownership (we estimate year 3 post-tax ROIC of 9.5%).
■ Anti-trust issues? This is a potential risk to the deal but management see a low
probability. There is a £28m break fee payable by Smiths.
■ Post deal valuation: Smiths would trade on a 2017E proforma PE of 13.3x vs.
16.2x for the sector. We view this deal as +ve for SMIN.

11:42 am
BE

Investec reckons it's a breakup play ..........

BE

Strategy. The proposed deal fits with the 'build not dispose' vibe from the new management team and it may be considered refreshing after years when expected deals did not materialise.

BE

UBS reckons it's the opposite ...........

11:42 am
BE

The price looks attractive if synergies are deliverable - the synergies are high in % of
sales terms (9% of sales), but not that large an absolute number and therefore could
be achievable via routes such as head office streamlining. The existing Smiths detection
business is in our view one of the less attractive assets in their portfolio. This deal
appears to improve the quality mix of that business. However, while moving one
business in the right direction, the overall ambitions of new management to increase
investment in the business still presents further challenges so we retain a Neutral rating.

BE

So, take your pick.

After falling 38% in 2015 StanChart has recovered in 2016 on a relative basis, up 40%
from its lows, roughly flat against a European banks index which is down around 13%
this year. With many funds short or underweight at the start of the year, commodity
prices regaining some poise, EM equities rallying and EM funds seeing a return to
inflows, a rally is directionally easy to rationalise.

BE

With consensus down 30-60% this leaves StanChart looking more pricey on EPS

BE

But the StanChart rally has happened against a ~60% fall in consensus profit forecasts
for this year and 30% decline for next. Our estimates are unchanged and so is our
view: we see great businesses within StanChart – predominantly Transaction Banking,
Financial Markets and bits of Retail – but we think the headwinds of de-risking,
deleveraging, and flat and low yield curves will combine with elevated loan losses to
make life particularly difficult near term (we forecast a loss for this year), leaving the
8% ROE target for 2018 out of reach.

11:53 am
BE

Cheap to book, expensive to earnings

BE

At a 35% discount to TNAV and sufficiently capitalised to weather these headwinds
some would see the share as cheap for the long term. That may be so. We choose to
value businesses based on the profits we expect, a basis upon which StanChart looks
distinctly over-extended in our view.

BE

Valuation: 14.4x 2017E, 9.2x 2018E EPS, 0.65x TNAV for a 7% ROTE in 2018E

11:54 am
BE

At 14.4x 2017E EPS StanChart trades at a material premium to scale banks it competes
with, ranging from 26% to Hong Kong banks, 34% to Singapore's, 56% to the
Europeans, and 200% to the Chinese. The premiums for 2018 earnings are also high.
Focussing on book value, 0.65x TNAV for a 7% ROTE two years hence implies a cost of
equity under 10%: considering the fears investors harboured about EM in general and
China in particular only a short while ago, we think this is too optimistic. Our SOTPderived
target rises to 430p (HK$48) from 410p (HK$47) on weaker Sterling: all other
estimates are unchanged. With 20% downside to our target we downgrade to Sell
from Neutral. Next catalyst: 1Q16 results due on Tuesday 26 April

11:58 am
BE

Virgin Money : God Save The Queen - Buy

BE

Which'd usually make me stop reading, but it's Ian Gordon so let's hear him out.

BE

For us, yesterday’s “deep dive” into Virgin’s cards business was both incrementally positive (on volumes) and reassuring in terms of evidencing the validity of its EIR accounting recognition. We suspect consensus may be slow to react – perhaps waiting for “validation” in the Q1 2016 IMS on 4 May? – but we do expect to see gentle upgrades over time. Moreover, today’s CML gross lending data for March of £25.7bn, up 59% YoY, up 43% MoM, offers further de facto confirmation that strong mortgage growth continues. BUY.

The most obvious takeaway from yesterday’s “cards spotlight” session is that Q1 2016 cards growth of £225m is tracking ahead of Virgin’s £60m p/m target. As such, we regard its ambition to grow balances from £1.6bn at end-2015 (a 2.5% market share) to c.£3bn by end-2017 as increasingly comfortable. We raise our end-2018e forecast to £3.9bn (from £3.8bn), which further underscores the positive mix effect that we expect to support NIM.
Perhaps the main purpose of Virgin’s presentation yesterday was (in its words) to dispel a number of popular myths. For us, one of the most important new disclosures relates to the (surprisingly high (?)) level of cash earnings achieved by Virgin during (extended) 0% promotional periods. In 2015, 66% of EIR income was earned on a cash basis from a combination of balance transfer fees, retail transactions and interest. This was largely attributed to high activity rates through proactive customer “stimulation”. (Just to “prove” the point, this author/customer actually received a text from Virgin cards offering a further promotional balance transfer rate during yesterday’s presentation!)
In 2015, only 34% of Virgin’s cards income was recognised under EIR accounting. 66% of income is cash accounted (relating to 2012 and prior vintages), with back-book yields in excess of 12%.
In 2015, cards contributed 22% of group revenues and 32% of u/l PBT, but represented 6% of customer loans. Virgin expects this to rise to 10% over time.
Buy recommendation reaffirmed. TP raised to 430p (from 425p). We see Virgin trading on 1.0x 2018e tNAV for a 2018e RoTE of 15.1% (previously 15.0%).
